page.title: 08TRESWELL WOOD
page.content: Treswell Wood is an ancient woodland. It was first mentioned in the Domesday Book. In Norman times it was used for grazing the swine and collecting firewood. Today the trees are being coppiced and the wood generally improved. It belongs to a Nature Trust. There is a nature trail there and we followed it as part of our school's survey work. We saw Damsel Flies and heard the warble of a Cuckoo over our heads. On either side of the path, Bluebells, Red Campions and Purple Orchids mingled their colours. Oak, Ash Hazel and Elm trees border the path. The Service tree is a rare local specimen. There have been lots of nest boxes provided and many types of birds can be seen. Cut wood is sold towards the upkeep of the property.
